prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Nearby Dwarf Galaxies: C34-7 CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3) and HCN (4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a survey of five dwarf galaxies with ALMA in Band 7 and configuration C34-5 and C34-7 aimed at observing the transition of CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) simultaneously at the centers of these galaxies in order to map the distribution and kinematics of the molecular gas and measure the mass of the central IMBH in these low-mass systems.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Assuming a lower IMBH mass end of M_BH ~ 10^3 solar masses and a stellar velocity dispersion of sigma ~ 10 km/s (e.g., Battaglia et al. 2008), the radius of the gravitational sphere of influence of the IMBH is estimated to have a value of r_infl = G M_BH /sigma^2 ~ 0.04 pc. With the spatial resolution of 0.12 arcsec/pix achieved by ALMA in configuration C34-7, it is possible to resolve such a low-mass BH in small galaxies out to a distance of ~ 140 kpc.
For Sgr dSph and SMC dI, the estimated CO luminosity is ~ 0.3 and ~ 0.35 K km/s, respectively, and we will use the C34 configuration that offers the highest resolution, C34-7, with a resolution of 0.12 arcsec. For Canis Major dI, we assume the predicted integrated line intensity of CO(3-2) of the Sgr dSph, i.e. ~ 0.3 K km/s. For the most distant of these three dwarf galaxies, i.e. the SMC dI (d=61 kpc), it will be possible to measure the steep velocity gradient introduced by a BH of mass 10^3 solar masses with ~ 3 resolution elements within the gravitational sphere of influence of the BH. For Canis Major dI (d=8 kpc) and Sgr dSph (d=20 kpc), we will have a factor of ~ 8 and ~ 3 more resolution elements within the gravitational sphere of influence of a BH of this mass, respectively, and will certainly be able to confirm the presence of a 9400 solar masses BH suggested by Ibata et al. (2009) at the dynamical center of Sgr dSph.
For Sculptor dSph and Sextans I dSph, the estimated CO luminosity is ~ 0.08 and ~ 0.1 K km/s, respectively, and we will use the C34 configuration with slightly lower resolution, C34-5, with a resolution of 0.22 arcsec, to reach our sensitivity limits in a shorter integration time. Therefore, for these two more distant dwarf galaxies in our sample (d=90 kpc), it will be possible to measure the steep velocity gradient introduced by a BH of mass 10^4 solar masses with ~ 10 resolution elements within the gravitational sphere of influence of the BH.
Our observations of five nearby dwarf galaxies with ALMA in Band 7 are aimed at observing the transition of CO(3-2), HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) simultaneously at the centers of these galaxies in order to map the distribution and kinematics of the molecular gas and measure the mass of the central IMBH in these low-mass systems. To estimate the exposure time at the representative frequency (rest) of 345.79599 GHz for CO(3-2), we used the ALMA Sensitivity Calculator. For our observations in the configuration C34-7 (Canis Major, Sgr dSph and SMC dI), we calculate the integration time required using the following set of parameters (here given for SMC): Dec: -72:49:43, Polarization: Dual, Observing frequency (Sky): 345.7910 GHz, Bandwidth per Polarization: 12 km/s, Water Vapour Column Density: Automatic Choice, Number of Antennas: 34, and Resolution: 0.12 arcsec. We find that with an integration time of 2.04h, we will achieve a sensitivity of 0.35 K in a 12 km/s bandwith (or 0.52 mJy). Including calibration and overheads, the total time required for the three targets is 15.95h. For our observations in the configuration C34-5 (Sculptor dSph and Sextans I dSph), we calculate the integration time required using the following set of parameters (here given for Sextans I dSph): Dec: -01:36:53, Polarization: Dual, Observing frequency (Sky): 345.7886 GHz, Bandwidth per Polarization: 12 km/s, Water Vapour Column Density: Automatic Choice, Number of Antennas: 34, and Resolution: 0.22 arcsec. We find that with an integration time of 2.05h, we will achieve a sensitivity of 0.1 K in a 12 km/s bandwith (or 0.5 mJy). Including calibration and overheads, the total time required for the two targets is 11.85h. It is therefore possible to observe all of our five targets in a total of 27.8h.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent findings suggest that intermediate-mass and supermassive black holes are generically present in all galaxy morphological types with stellar masses ranging from ~ 10^7 to 10^12 solar masses. In particular, the massive black holes in low-mass galaxies are important to study as they can provide valuable clues to the origin of the black hole/galaxy scaling relations observed at the present epoch and the formation of massive black hole at earlier times. In order to establish that these massive black holes do exist at the centers of dwarf galaxies, dynamical mass estimates must be obtained. We propose a survey of nearby dwarf galaxies with ALMA in Band 7 aimed at mapping the distribution and kinematics of the molecular gas at the centers of these galaxies and obtaining the black hole dynamical mass estimates in these low-mass systems. With these and future high-resolution ALMA observations, we aim to map the molecular gas in the immediate vicinity of the central black hole in nearby dwarf galaxies, study the black hole demographics and the relationships between black holes and their hosts in the low-mass regime, and clarify their connection to their higher mass counterparts.
